question: Question_09_(a)
statement:
Use an appropriate line approximation to estimate
\emph{e\textsuperscript{0.1}}.
sols:
The linear approximation formula is

\[f(x) \approx L(x) = f'(a)(x-a) + f(a)\]

For some value \emph{a} that is near the value to be approximated. In
our case, $f(x) = e^x$ and a sensible choice for \emph{a} would be
\emph{0} as it is easy to calculate $\displaystyle f(0) = e^0$ and
$\displaystyle f'(0) = e^0$. Plugging this into our formula for
\emph{L(x)} we have:

\[\displaystyle L(x) = e^0(x - 0) + e^0\]

\[\displaystyle L(x) = x + 1\]

To approximate $e^{0.1}$, we simply plug in $x = 0.1$ to get

\[\displaystyle L(0.1) = 0.1 + 1 = 1.1\]
hints:
The linear approximation method requires choosing a value that is easy
to calculate (usually denoted by the variable \emph{a}), near the value
being approximated. What would be a good choice for this question?
